title: SSRF - pivoting in the private LAN

profile.name: Concrete CMS
profile.about: A simple and powerful content management system.

vulnerability_information:
The upload from remote servers features allows me to perform SSRF attack on the private LAN servers.

this features checks the following
* http response code needs to be 200 - easy, a non issue for attackers really
* checks the file exension   (can be bypassed with something like  http://192.168.1.148/index.php/test.png  - anything after index.php/  is ignorred and I control the file extension as well)
* some checks are performed on the IP, but any public and PRIVATE ips are allowed

I can read web  apps from the internal network, fingerprint them and exploit them (using GET only exploits).

This is how I've managed to read an phpinfo file from my local LAN:

http://192.168.1.157/info.php/test.html

The file is fetched, saved by the CMS locally (or S3) and then the output can be downloaded by the attacker as you can see in the attached screenshots.

ps: crayons

## Impact

An attacker can pivot in the private LAN and exploit local network apps.

activities.message:
Hi Adrian,
Thanks for this report. This is quite similar to a different report we resolved recently #1102105 and it looks like we haven't completely solved the problem.

The best way to resolve this issue is to filter local IPs differently than we filter remote IPs. Today we simply allow both, instead we should consider disabling local IP importing all together, or at least putting it behind some sort of flag or allow-list so that users that rely on it can enable it and everyone else can be protected by default.

Thanks,
Korvin

Hi Korvin,

I can't see that report I'm afraid, but I had the impression as well that this was exploited previously.  I think you should consider disabling local ips all together.

If you want to use a whitelist, this should only be doable by someone with the highest privileges (like superadmin). Or perhaps it would be even better to enable this only if you have the permission to change a setting in the configuration file, to make it even harder for attackers (more privileges needed).

Hello @adrian_t   CVE-2021-22970 has been created for Concrete CMS versions 9.0 and below and 8.5.6 and below allowing local IP importing causing the system to be vulnerable to your attack and the attack described by another reporter in https://hackerone.com/reports/1360016.  We will credit both you and the other reporter in the release notes for 9.0.1 and 8.5.7 both due to be released next week.  Please don't disclose until then. Thanks.
@adrian_t sorry, I we can't commit to the exact date.

@lisaciso we appreciate even an approximate date, like mid-week, or towards the end of the week....etc

thanks.
@adrian_t we are aiming for Monday for both 8.5.7 and 9.0.1 barring something unforeseen.
@adrian_t releases have been pushed out a couple days...hence why I was hesitant to commit to a date.
@lisaciso no problem, as I said I was interested in an approximate date.....sometimes I just want to know if we're talking days/weeks/months when talking about releasing a patch for a vulnerability.
